items.title: Daily Digest: Saturday, 7 February 2026
items.summary: AI and technology news digest for Saturday, 7 February 2026
items.contentHtml:
# Daily Digest: Saturday, 7 February 2026

Welcome to today's roundup of the most interesting developments in AI and technology.

## Industry

### AI companies want you to stop chatting with bots and start managing them

Claude Opus 4.6 and OpenAI Frontier pitch a future of supervising AI agents.

Read more

### Apple might let you use ChatGPT from CarPlay

CarPlay users could soon be able to use their chatbot of choice instead of Siri. As Bloomberg reports, Apple is working to add support for CarPlay voice control apps from OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, and others. Previously, users who wanted to access third-party chatbots in the car would need to go through their iPhone, but soon […]

Read more

### Benchmark raises $225M in special funds to double down on Cerebras

Benchmark Capital has been an investor in the Nvidia rival since 2016.

Read more

### From Svedka to Anthropic, brands make bold plays with AI in Super Bowl ads

From the first AI-generated Big Game ad courtesy of Svedka to Anthropic's beef with OpenAI, here are the biggest ads from Super Bowl LX.

Read more

### How Epstein became a tech influencer

There are bold-faced tech names all over the Epstein files. Elon Musk, Bill Gates, Sergey Brin, Eric Schmidt, Larry Page, Reid Hoffman, Steven Sinofsky, Peter Thiel, Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg, on and on and on. These men (and they're pretty much all men) had wildly varying degrees of interaction with Epstein, and the details matter […]

Read more

### How the men in the Epstein files defeated #MeToo

He might be dead, but it sure seems like Jeffrey Epstein won. Sure, Epstein was arrested on charges of sex trafficking minors. Sure, he died in jail. (I am not going to wade into the debate about how.) But he subscribed to a racist, misogynist ideology that meant rich white men like him could do […]

Read more

### Increase of AI bots on the Internet sparks arms race

Publishers are rolling out more aggressive defenses.

Read more

### It just got easier for Claude to check in on your WordPress site

WordPress users can now leverage Claude to analyze web traffic or find information about other internal site metrics.

Read more

### Malicious packages for dYdX cryptocurrency exchange empties user wallets

Incident is at least the third time the exchange has been targeted by thieves.

Read more

### Maybe AI agents can be lawyers after all

This week's release of Opus 4.6 shook up the agentic AI leaderboards.

Read more

### New York lawmakers propose a three-year pause on new data centers

Although the bill‚Äôs prospects are uncertain, New York is at least the sixth state to consider pausing construction of new data centers.

Read more

### OpenAI is hoppin' mad about Anthropic's new Super Bowl TV ads

Sam Altman calls AI competitor "dishonest" and "authoritarian" in lengthy post on X.

Read more

### Sixteen Claude AI agents working together created a new C compiler

The $20,000 experiment compiled a Linux kernel but needed deep human management.

Read more

### Super Bowl LX ads: all AI everything

Super Bowl LX is nearly here, with the Seattle Seahawks taking on the New England Patriots. While Bad Bunny will be the star of the halftime show, AI could be the star of the commercial breaks, much like crypto was a few years ago. Last year‚Äôs Super Bowl featured a Google Gemini ad that fumbled […]

Read more

### What happens when Waymo runs into a tornado? Or an elephant?

An autonomous vehicle drives down a lonely stretch of highway. Suddenly, a massive tornado appears in the distance. What does the driverless vehicle do next? This is just one of the scenarios that Waymo can simulate in the "hyper realistic" virtual world that it has just created with help from Google's DeepMind. Waymo's World Model […]

Read more

## Research

### D4RT: Teaching AI to see the world in four dimensions

D4RT: Unified, efficient 4D reconstruction and tracking up to 300x faster than prior methods.

Read more

### Gemini 3 Flash: frontier intelligence built for speed

Gemini 3 Flash offers frontier intelligence built for speed at a fraction of the cost.

Read more

### Google's year in review: 8 areas with research breakthroughs in 2025

Google 2025 recap: Research breakthroughs of the year

Read more

### Project Genie: Experimenting with infinite, interactive worlds

Google AI Ultra subscribers in the U.S. can try out Project Genie, an experimental research prototype that lets you create and explore worlds.

Read more

### Veo 3.1 Ingredients to Video: More consistency, creativity and control

Our latest Veo update generates lively, dynamic clips that feel natural and engaging ‚Äî and supports vertical video generation.

Read more

## Models

### GPT-5 lowers the cost of cell-free protein synthesis

An autonomous lab combining OpenAI‚Äôs GPT-5 with Ginkgo Bioworks‚Äô cloud automation cut cell-free protein synthesis costs by 40% through closed-loop experimentation.

Read more

### How Google Cloud is helping Team USA elevate their tricks with AI

A woman outdoors in the snow looks at a tablet. A half pipe is behind her.

Read more

### How we‚Äôre helping preserve the genetic information of endangered species with AI

A four-part vertical collage showing a cotton-top tamarin, an ibex, a golden lion tamarin, and a penguin.

Read more

### Introducing OpenAI Frontier

OpenAI Frontier is an enterprise platform for building, deploying, and managing AI agents with shared context, onboarding, permissions, and governance.

Read more

### Introducing Trusted Access for Cyber

OpenAI introduces Trusted Access for Cyber, a trust-based framework that expands access to frontier cyber capabilities while strengthening safeguards against misuse.

Read more

### Korea privacy policy

Korea privacy policy

Read more

### Making AI work for everyone, everywhere: our approach to localization

OpenAI shares its approach to AI localization, showing how globally shared frontier models can be adapted to local languages, laws, and cultures without compromising safety.

Read more

### Natively Adaptive Interfaces: A new framework for AI accessibility

A collage of four images, the first of a woman with curly hair in front of a silver laptop, the second of the same woman and a man with short black hair speaking on a stairwell, the third of a the same man with glasses, and an aerial image of NTID

Read more

### The latest AI news we announced in January

mp4 showing a carousel of images including a card reading "Help that's made for you"

Read more

### Watch our new Gemini ad ahead of football‚Äôs biggest weekend

A toddler in a blue and yellow striped shirt sits on a kitchen counter eating a red apple. Text in the corner reads: 'New Home, Google Gemini SB Commercial‚Äô

Read more

## Tools

### Stability AI and EA Partner to Empower Artists, Designers, and Developers to Reimagine Game Development

Stability AI and Electronic Arts (EA) have formed a strategic partnership

to co-develop transformative generative AI models, tools, and workflows

that empower EA‚Äôs artists, designers, and developers to reimagine how games

are made.

Read more

### Stability AI Brings Image Services to Amazon Bedrock, Delivering End-to-End Creative Control with Enterprise-Grade Infrastructure

Today, we're excited to announce we‚Äôre expanding our partnership with

Amazon Web Services to bring our Stable Image Services to Amazon Bedrock.

Read more

### Stability AI‚Äôs Annual Integrity Transparency Report

At Stability AI, we are committed to building and deploying generative AI

responsibly, and we believe that transparency is foundational to safe and

ethical AI.

Read more

### Universal Music Group and Stability AI Announce Strategic Alliance to Co-Develop Professional AI Music Creation Tools

Universal Music Group and Stability AI today announced a strategic alliance

to develop next-generation professional music creation tools, powered by

responsibly trained generative AI and¬†built to support the creative process

of artists, producers and songwriters globally.

Read more

### Warner Music Group and Stability AI Join Forces To Build The Next Generation Of Responsible AI Tools For Music Creation

Warner Music Group and Stability AI today announced a collaborative effort

to advance the use of responsible AI in music creation, combining WMG‚Äôs

long-standing advocacy for principled innovation with Stability AI‚Äôs

expertise and leadership in commercially-safe generative audio.

Read more
This digest was automatically generated.

items.title: My 2026 AI Predictions
items.summary: Bold predictions for how AI will transform our world in 2026 - from coding agents to creative tools.
items.contentHtml:
# My 2026 AI Predictions

As we enter 2026, I'm making some bold predictions about where AI is heading this year. Some of these might age poorly, but that's half the fun.

## The Rise of AI Agents

2025 was the year of chatbots. 2026 will be the year of agents.

We've already seen early examples with tools like Claude Code, Devin, and various coding assistants. But this year, I expect:

  • Autonomous task completion - Give an agent a goal, come back to completed work
  • Multi-step reasoning - Agents that can break down complex problems
  • Tool use at scale - Seamless integration with APIs, databases, and services
  • Collaboration between agents - Teams of specialised AI workers
"The best AI won't replace humans - it will amplify what we can do."

## Predictions Table

PredictionConfidenceTimeframe
AI agents become mainstream dev toolsHighQ1-Q2
Major creative tool gets AI overhaulHighQ2
First AI-generated film nominated for awardMediumQ4
Coding bootcamps pivot to "AI-assisted development"HighQ1
Open-source model matches GPT-4 qualityMediumQ3
AI regulation passes in EUHighQ2-Q3

## What I'm Most Excited About

### 1. Creative AI Tools

The gap between imagination and creation is shrinking. Tools like Midjourney, Suno, and Runway are already impressive, but 2026 will bring:

  • Real-time video generation
  • Music that adapts to your mood
  • Design tools that understand intent, not just prompts

### 2. Personal AI Assistants

Not the "hey Siri" kind. I mean AI that:

  1. Knows your preferences deeply
  2. Manages your calendar intelligently
  3. Drafts emails in your voice
  4. Learns from your feedback

### 3. Developer Experience

As someone who codes daily, I'm watching this space closely:

# 2025: Write code, AI suggests completions
def calculate_total(items):
    return sum(item.price for item in items)

# 2026: Describe intent, AI writes implementation
# "Create a function that calculates cart total with
#  tax, discounts, and shipping based on location"

The shift from autocomplete to autoimplement is coming.

## What Concerns Me

Not everything is rosy. Here's what keeps me up at night:

  • Misinformation at scale - Deepfakes, synthetic media, fake news
  • Job displacement - Some roles will change dramatically
  • Concentration of power - Big tech vs everyone else
  • Environmental cost - Training these models isn't cheap

## My Bet for 2026

If I had to make one prediction I'm most confident about:

By December 2026, the average developer will spend more time reviewing AI-generated code than writing it from scratch.

We're already seeing this shift. GitHub Copilot users report 40%+ of their code comes from AI suggestions. That number will only grow.

## Let's Revisit in December

I'll be back at the end of 2026 to score these predictions. Feel free to hold me accountable!

What are your predictions for AI in 2026? I'd love to hear them.

Written on New Year's Day 2026, fuelled by optimism and too much coffee.

items.title: Building My AI Agent Workspace
items.summary: How I set up a multi-AI workspace with Claude Code, Gemini CLI, and Codex CLI working together.
items.contentHtml:
# Building My AI Agent Workspace

I've spent the last few weeks building something I'm genuinely excited about: a workspace where multiple AI agents collaborate on tasks. Here's how it works.

## The Setup

I run three AI agents simultaneously:

AgentRoleStrengths
Claude CodeOrchestratorTask management, coding, workspace automation
Gemini CLIResearcherGoogle Search, large file analysis, knowledge base
Codex CLITechnical LeadAdvanced coding, architecture, code review

Each agent has access to the same workspace folder, shared documentation, and a simple coordination system.

## The Coordination System

Rather than complex protocols, I use an ultra-simple approach:

### 1. Shared Updates Log

All agents write to a single UPDATES.md file:

## 2026-01-01

### Claude Code - 14:30
Completed task: Set up new build system
Next: Testing deployment pipeline

### Gemini CLI - 15:45
Research complete: OAuth 2.0 best practices
Created: Research/oauth-security.md

### 2. Handoff Files

When one agent needs another to continue work:

---
from: Claude Code
to: Gemini CLI
priority: high
---

# Research Request: Discord Bot APIs

## Context
Building automation tools, need to understand Discord's bot ecosystem.

## Requirements
- [ ] ToS for automation
- [ ] Rate limits
- [ ] Available APIs

### 3. Simple Rules

  • Full workspace access - No protected areas (trust the agents)
  • UK English throughout - Consistency matters
  • Log everything - Future agents need context

## Why Multiple Agents?

You might ask: "Why not just use one AI?"

Great question. Here's my reasoning:

  1. Specialisation - Each model has strengths
  2. Parallel work - Research while coding
  3. Cross-verification - Different perspectives catch errors
  4. Context limits - Split large tasks across agents

## Real Example: This Website

This very website was built using this multi-agent approach:

  1. Claude Code wrote the build script and templates
  2. Gemini CLI researched static site best practices
  3. Codex CLI reviewed the architecture

The result? A cleaner codebase than any single agent (or human) would produce alone.

## Lessons Learned

### What Works

  • Simple coordination beats complex protocols
  • Shared context is everything
  • Let agents play to their strengths
  • Trust but verify - Review AI output

### What Doesn't Work

  • Micromanaging agents
  • Overly complex handoff procedures
  • Assuming agents remember previous sessions
  • Forgetting to provide context

## The Future

I'm convinced this is the future of knowledge work:

Humans set direction. Agents do execution. Everyone wins.

We're not there yet - there's still plenty of supervision needed. But the trajectory is clear.

## Try It Yourself

If you want to experiment with multi-agent workflows:

  1. Start with one agent, master it
  2. Add a second for specific tasks
  3. Create simple coordination rules
  4. Iterate based on what works

The tools are available today. The question is: what will you build?

This post was drafted by Claude Code, fact-checked by Gemini CLI, and reviewed by a human (me).

items.title: Welcome to Kol's Korner
items.summary: Welcome to my new site! Here I'll share thoughts on tech, AI, and development.
items.contentHtml:
# Welcome

Hello and welcome to my new site!

## What to Expect

I'll be sharing:

  • Tech insights - Latest developments in software
  • AI explorations - Experiments and discoveries
  • Development tips - Things I've learned along the way

## About This Site

This site is built from Obsidian markdown files and hosted on GitHub Pages. No databases, no complicated CMS - just simple markdown files that get transformed into a static site.

## Stay Tuned

More content coming soon. Feel free to explore and check back regularly!

Thanks for visiting!

items.title: Markdown Formatting Guide
items.summary: A comprehensive reference for all the markdown formatting supported on this site.
items.contentHtml:
# Markdown Formatting Guide

This post demonstrates all the markdown formatting supported on this site. Use it as a reference when writing your own posts.

## Text Formatting

Basic text formatting options:

  • Bold text using double asterisks
  • Italic text using single asterisks
  • Bold and italic using triple asterisks
  • Inline code using backticks

You can also use underscores: italic and bold.

## Headings

Headings use hash symbols and get red hash styling:

# Heading 1
## Heading 2
### Heading 3

Each heading automatically gets an ID for linking.

## Lists

### Unordered Lists

  • First item
  • Second item
  • Third item with a longer description that might wrap to multiple lines

### Ordered Lists

  1. First step
  2. Second step
  3. Third step

## Blockquotes

This is a blockquote. Use it for highlighting important quotes or callouts.

>

It can span multiple paragraphs.

## Code Blocks

Inline code: const x = 42;

Fenced code blocks with syntax highlighting:

// JavaScript example
function greet(name) {
  return `Hello, ${name}!`;
}

console.log(greet('World'));
# Python example
def greet(name):
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

print(greet("World"))
/* CSS example */
.container {
  display: flex;
  justify-content: center;
  align-items: center;
}

## Tables

Tables are great for structured data:

FeatureStatusNotes
Dark mode‚úÖ DoneToggle in header
RSS feedüöß PlannedComing soon
Comments‚ùå No plansUse social media

Alignment options:

LeftCentreRight
TextTextText
MoreMoreMore

## Links

  • External link
  • Link with title

## Horizontal Rules

Use three dashes for a horizontal rule:

Or three asterisks:

## Images

Images use the standard markdown syntax:

![Alt text](path/to/image.jpg)

## Combining Elements

You can combine elements for rich formatting:

Note: This is an important callout that combines:
- Bold text
- A list
- And a blockquote

### Example: API Response

Here's a typical API response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "id": 123,
    "name": "Example",
    "tags": ["one", "two", "three"]
  }
}
FieldTypeDescription
statusstringResponse status
dataobjectResponse payload
data.idnumberUnique identifier

## Best Practices

  1. Use headings hierarchically - Don't skip levels
  2. Keep paragraphs short - Easier to read
  3. Use lists for multiple items - Better than comma-separated
  4. Add alt text to images - Accessibility matters
  5. Preview before publishing - Catch formatting issues
This guide covers the most common markdown features. Happy writing!
